All Product Information Customer Q&A's Customer Reviews

From the manufacturer

SainSmart 4-Channel 5V Relay Module

View larger

Package Content:

1 x SainSmart 4-Channel 5V Relay Module

More Manual instruction please refer to our site.

SainSmart 4-Channel 5V Relay Module

5V 4-Channel Relay interface board, and each one needs 15-20mA Driver Current

- Equiped with high-current relay, AC250V 10A ; DC30V 10A.

- Standard interface that can be controlled directly by microcontroller (Arduino , 8051, AVR, PIC, DSP, ARM, ARM, MSP430, TTL logic active low).

- Opto-isolated inputs.

- Indication LED’s for Relay output status.

Read more
View larger

Product information

This is a 5V 4-Channel Relay interface board, be able to control various appliances, and other equipments with large current.

It can be controlled directly by Microcontroller (Arduino, 8051, AVR, PIC, DSP, ARM, ARM, MSP430, TTL logic).

Item weight: 0.2 pounds.

Read more

Product description

Product Packaging:Standard Packaging

This is a 5V 4-Channel Relay interface board, Be able to control various appliances, and other equipments with large current. It can be controlled directly by Microcontroller (Arduino, 8051, AVR, PIC, DSP, ARM, ARM, MSP430, TTL logic).

Product information

Product Packaging:Standard Packaging
Product Dimensions 4.5 x 3.2 x 1.2 inches
Item Weight 1.12 ounces

Top customer reviews

There was a problem filtering reviews right now. Please try again later.

Denis Dimick
5.0 out of 5 starsWorks great
September 4, 2017
Package Type: Standard Packaging|Verified Purchase
I installed these into my Jeep to drive some high current accessories, so I was worried about current draw when the vehicle wasn't running. They have very low current draw, and I've gone up to a week without starting my Jeep and there wasn't any issues.

The relays also have diodes across the relays to prevent high voltage spikes when the relays have power removed, so while this isn't specified in the package info, it's nice to see them installed.

The only issue I've run into was due to my own stupidity, I drug +12volts across the PCB and blew out 2 of the LED indicator lamps. While they no longer work, the relays work perfectly.
Read more

WVUTampaAlum
5.0 out of 5 starsWorks perfect for my raspberry pi automated sprinkler system
August 13, 2016
Package Type: Standard Packaging|Verified Purchase
Works perfect for my raspberry pi automated sprinkler system. My home sprinkler unit topped working and so I had a complete sprinkler system with no controller. The main (12v) power also was still working. With only this part I now have a raspberry pi online automated sprinkler system. NOTE that I did already have a working wifi connected raspberry pi. With the free open source SIP software and this inexpensive board I now have a fully online connected sprinkler. Follow following link for all information to download and install SIP sprinkler software.[...]

1.0 out of 5 starsTerrible quality
September 22, 2017
Package Type: Standard Packaging|Verified Purchase
would have been perfect for my project but instead i wasted time and money on a product that shouldnt have passed a visual QC check, let alone a functional QC check. Out of 4 relays, only 3 are functional as D3 is missing. Worse, i cant even just reflow a new diode into the spot as there are no markings or color bands on the diodes nor do sainsmarts documents include part numbers on the available schematics. My best guess would be a 5v 500ma zerner but i'm not certain and would rather not risk my input device. So what could have been a 2 minute fix for something that shouldnt have been reqyuired, i have to deal with the week or more amazon returns will take

Jw
5.0 out of 5 starsGood
December 21, 2013
Package Type: Standard Packaging|Verified Purchase
I wasn't able to hook this up to my Arduino for almost a month after receiving it. After I got it working, I was able to run a few tests but then all of a sudden it stopped responding (and of course 4 days past the Amazon return window). I tested each leg of the circuit and re-checked my code, but to no avail. Rather than posting a 1-star review, I emailed the seller to explain my situation and they immediately sent me a replacement! Hooked the new one up and it works perfectly - I am now switching some 120V AC circuits and 12V DC circuits with ease the way it was intended. Although I ran into a hiccup at first, SainStore provided great customer service which kept me a happy customer. I have purchased other items from them before and will continue to look for the name of this seller when determining who to purchase from.

ArizonaDan
5.0 out of 5 starsI'm Happy. Works as Advertised
September 22, 2012
Package Type: Standard Packaging|Verified Purchase
When I got my relay board in the mail, I couldn't wait to connect it to my Arduino (Duemilenove) and try and control some relays with a sketch I had previously written. The board didn't include any documentation, however I was able to do a quick Google search and find what I needed. I found a schematic which illustrated how to connect the board. +5V to VCC, GND to my Arduino's Digital GND, and also that the board requires the pinState set to LOW to cause the relay to close. The load side of the relay can be wired up to be NC/NO.

I was happy with everything about the board. It worked just fine, looks like good quality workmanship coming from the SainSmart company which I understand is a "knockoff" maker of Arduino shields in China. I was able to use the board to successfully switch 120Vac to a bedroom lamp by cutting one of the cord's leads and wiring each end to the relay's output.

I would not recommend using more than +5v to power the relays because when I used +9v, the relay closed and would not open when the trigger signal was switched LOW.

I plan on buying more of the relays present on this board for discrete applications in my home automation project.
Read more
0Comment| 2 people found this helpful. Was this review helpful to you?
Yes
No
Report abuse
DTBarber
5.0 out of 5 starsWell Built Relay Module
February 28, 2015
Package Type: Standard Packaging|Verified Purchase
This is a very well made relay module. There are diodes on the relays to protect a microcontroller from back EMF. There is a jumper on the VCC that can be used to create an emergency stop switch. There is a status LED on each relay. Each relay has three connections: common, normally open, and normally closed. As others have commented, use directions are poor at best, but controlling a specific relay with a microcontroller simply requires pulling the relay pin low to turn it on and setting it high to turn the relay off. I would prefer screw terminals for connecting a microcontroller to the module versus the straight 6-pin header strip, but that is a small inconvenience.
Read more
